comments.body: imo we should require no whitespace before it given how simple these files are

oh I see, the intention is to put it on the same line as the package.
I guess this is fine since go packages likely cannot contain `#` in their path, otherwise I'd suggest having comment _lines_ that start with `#` exactly.

Thanks for reviewing, @BenTheElder!

Yes, the idea is that the comments are inline with the package paths. The file becomes more compact, so it's easier to see what paths are related. If the file is ever automatically sorted, which [kube::util::check-file-in-alphabetical-order](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/hack/lib/util.sh#L712-L727) will instruct you to do if it's not, the comment will stay with the package name.

What do you think is the best action to take here? I'm happy to make any changes :)
IMO this is the best option, I would have marked these comments resolved, but I can't :(
Goodie. Thanks ðŸ™Œ

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +48,52 @@while IFS='' read -r line; do all_packages+=("$line"); done < <(go list -e ./... | grep -vE "/(third_party|vendor|staging/src/k8s.io/client-go/pkg|generated|clientset_generated)" | sed -e 's|^k8s.io/kubernetes/||' -e "s|^_\(${KUBE_ROOT}/\)\{0,1\}||")
# The regex below removes any "#" character and anything behind it and including any
# whitespace before it. Then it removes empty lines.
failing_packages=()
while IFS='' read -r line; do failing_packages+=("$line"); done < <(sed -e 's/[[:blank:]]*#.*//' -e '/^$/d' "$failure_file")

comments.body: `mapfile -t failing_packages < "$failure_file"` would probably be better. But not in this PR.

I wonder if perhaps we should `| awk '{print $1}'` or something when we cat the file in, so that we could possibly add comments to the failure file.. have some sort of trail of why the failure exists, or a PR/Issue to look at.
While I like the idea, I think it's out of the scope of the PR and it might be tricky to implement. For instance, if line numbers change then the failure reason is now outdated.
@stevekuznetsov does this do what it's supposed to do?  It doesn't have to be the pinnacle of beauty, it just needs to work.

You're running `#!/bin/bash` -- always use `[[` over `[`. If using `[[`, use `&&` and `||` for logic. If you must be POSIX compliant, use `[` and `-a` and `-o`. Access to empty arrays with `-o nounset` is tricky but `${#array[@]}` is safe.

comments.body:
More readable would be

```sh
if ! array_contains "${p}" "${all_packages[@]}"; then
    gone+=( "${p}" )
fi
```

diffHunk:

for p in "${linted_packages[@]}"; do
	array_contains "$p" "${all_packages[@]}" || gone+=( "$p" )
done

comments.body: :+1: Interesting concept. I can only hope that failing because you've made something more awesome doesn't trip anybody up. Should at least be strictly more pleasant than finding another flake.

lol yeah figure it will happen a couple times then be fine like all things
turned on at first ;)
